raw_text:
Halo 2 sells five million copies
 
 Microsoft is celebrating bumper sales of its Xbox sci-fi shooter, Halo 2.
 
 The game has sold more than five million copies worldwide since it went on sale in mid-November, the company said. Halo 2 has proved popular online, with gamers notching up a record 28 million hours playing the game on Xbox Live. According to Microsoft, nine out of 10 Xbox Live members have played the game for an average of 91 minutes per session.
 
 The sequel to the best-selling Need for Speed: Underground has inched ahead of the competition to take the top slot in the official UK games charts. The racing game moved up one spot to first place, nudging GTA: San Andreas down to second place. Halo 2 dropped one place to five, while Half-Life 2 fell to number nine. Last week's new releases, GoldenEye: Rogue Agent and Killzone, both failed to make it into the top 10, debuting at number 11 and 12 respectively.
 
 Record numbers of Warcraft fans are settling in the games online world. On the opening day of the World of Warcraft massive multi-player online game more than 200,000 players signed up to play. On the evening of the first day more than 100,000 players were in the world, forcing Blizzard to add another 34 servers to cope with the influx. The online game turns the stand alone Warcraft games into a persistent world that players can inhabit not just visit
 
 Europe's gamers could be waiting until January to hear when they can get their mitts on Nintendo's handheld device, Nintendo DS, says gamesindustry.biz. David Yarnton, Nintendo UK general manager, told a press conference to look out for details in the New Year. Its US launch was on Sunday and it goes on sale in Japan on 2 December. Nintendo has a 95% share of the handheld gaming market and said it expected to sell around five million of the DS by March 2005.
llama3.2:1b: Halo 2 sells over 5 million copies worldwide, more than Need for Speed: Underground. The game has sold over 28 million hours online on Xbox Live, with nine out of ten Xbox Live members playing for 91 minutes per session. Halo 2 dropped from fifth to five in the UK games charts. Record numbers of Warcraft fans are playing the online World of Warcraft game, which saw more than 300,000 players sign up on opening day and over 100,000 players visit by evening. Nintendo's handheld device, the Nintendo DS, is expected to launch early in the new year with a 95% share of the handheld gaming market and around five million potential sales by March 2005.
llama3.2:3b: Halo 2 sells over 5 million copies, with 28 million hours played online. Microsoft's Xbox game has surpassed Need for Speed: Underground 2 in UK sales charts. Record numbers play World of Warcraft on launch day, forcing Blizzard to add servers. Nintendo DS release delayed until January in Europe.
gemma2:2b: Halo 2 sold five million copies worldwide since its release, with high player engagement on Xbox Live.  It topped UK games charts and was surpassed only by Need for Speed: Underground in popularity. The World of Warcraft online game saw a record influx of players, forcing the developers to add servers. Nintendo's handheld device, the DS, is expected to launch in Japan on December 2nd, with a release date for Europe anticipated after January.

- Several other games have also been released recently: Need for Speed: Underground, GTA San Andreas, and Half-Life 2. Only Halo 2 moved up one position to number five in the UK games charts. 

Note that some details about European gamers being able to play Nintendo DS online were not mentioned in the text provided but can be found later in the article.

World of Warcraft attracted record-breaking numbers online on its launch day, with over 200,000 players signing up in the first 24 hours. Halo 2 has sold over five million copies since its release in mid-November, making it one of the best-selling online games worldwide. It has achieved online dominance with an impressive 28 million hours played on Xbox Live, averaging nearly 91 minutes per session for nine out of ten Xbox Live members. The sequel to Need for Speed: Underground has moved ahead of competitors to take the top slot in the official UK games charts, while Halo 2 and Half-Life 2 have dropped spots, with Halo 2 ending at five and Half-Life 2 dropping to number nine.  

On the online front, Blizzard reports over 200,000 players signed up for World of Warcraft on the opening day, and by evening, 100,000 were in the world, necessitating additional servers. The platform has redefined its role as a persistent, self-contained game environment.  

North Kyoto has announced that Nintendo DS handheld devices are expected to be available later in the year, with the US launch on Sunday and Japan's release on December 2nd. Nintendo holds a 95% share of the handheld gaming market, predicting sales of around five million by March 2005.

GTA: San Andreas dropped one place to second place, while Half-Life 2 fell to fifth. On the opening day of Warcraft, more than 200,000 players signed up to play the game. Nintendo's handheld device, the DS, is expected to sell around five million units by March 2005, with sales of the console and the Nintendo Gamecube also in high demand among UK consumers.
